div1.opener: United States Consulate St Paul de Loanda 25 January 1881
div1.p: Sir I have to report the arrival here on the 3rd January of the Whaler "Alatua" of New Bedford, she having been obliged to feed into ports as the crew refused to continue in the vessel they having shipped for 18 months are the time having expired, and the captain wishing them to continue the voyage for 18 months longer.

I tried to induce them to reship in the vessel, as they had no complaints of importance to make against the officers and also as this is the most unhealthy season here I was anxious not to hand the men as it is so difficult to get them shipped from port to Europe.

However my reasoning had us effect, and I had to dishcarge the following, taking the usual three
three months extra wages:- William R Clifford Joseph L. Noonan William Walton William Kuke Frederick Johnson D. H. Cruwell Herbert L. Keru Riley P. Squires William James Coville Lacrosse William H. Griffiths Matthew Thomas Peter John and Daniel Lefer, who was, a Deserter from the "Clarisse, and did not belong to the crew of the "Alatina" and was picked up at Calrinda

Eight of these men I shipped in the "Benin" for Haure, or Liverpool, and 6 by Portuguese Steamer "Bengo" for Lisbon. For the former I had to pay $389.00 passage money; & R 30 gratification to the Portuguese Captain of the "Bengo", all of which I will account for in my Quarterly a/c of the Relief fund.

I obtained 12 natives (Calrindas) to ship for 18 Months which made up the compliment of the crew required for the vessel again to put to
to sea These men are shipped on the conditions that when the time of 18 Months expires they are to be landed either here or at Ambriz

This is the first time that the Natives have shipped from this port in a Whaler & should they return satisfied I am certain there will be little difficulty in getting sailors for any other vessels of the same class that may come here requiring a crew.

The captian of the "Platua" was exceedingly pleased with this port as fresh provisions can always be obtained in abundance and at reasonable rates; & the only obstacle that prevented the Whalers from coming here, he thought was the port changes & formalition required by the Custom House.

As I think it would be of great advantage to the Whalers to come here instead of going to Calrinda, I leave made application to His Excellency
Excellency the Governor General to obtain a reduction of the usual dues levied on Whaling Vessels and also to allow the oil to be shipped free of any export duty should they wish to send it home from this port.
As soon as I get a reply I will advise the Department
I have the honor to be Sir, Your obedient Servant Rob S Newton Vice Consul
To the Assistant Secretary of State Washington D.C.
